bibl.title: [Letter] Aug. 20, 1919, [Gatlinburg, Tennessee to] family
bibl.note: Mrs. Helmick's visit. Man teacher Mr. Cresswell arrives - Picnic for schoolgirls -

projectDesc.p: Created for the University of Tennessee Digital Library

div1.p: Dearest family - Nine p.m. Wednesday and am ready for bed but will scribble off a few hasty lines to "you all" first. Wonder what the news in your midst is by this time. Sent off two more film packs to Knoxville today for developing & am so anxious to see them - for have had some fine subjects! As soon as they come will send them to you.

My last letter left off with the sing I think did it not? Usually three musicians come who play violin guitar and banjo - one of them does most of the singing & everyone sits around quietly and listens in the most serious way. They are all very mournful or gruesome tales but on the other hand perfectly ludicrous - One of recent origin is on the death of Wm. McKinley - who "while
shaking hands one said "I'm shot" in a quiet way " They go on interminably - "Charming Betsy" is another - "Cynthy" - "Sourwood Mt." "Boston Girl" - (a most bloody tale) The music sounds very much the same - & has a decided rhythm to which they tap time with their feet while playing - It was held in Mrs. Helmick's honor you know - She is really a remarkable woman - her husband is Gen. H. as I probably told you! As Emily & I were off all day Saturday. Sunday a.m. we scuttled around & cleaned downstairs going to Sunday School at 9 - There is no minister here for all the time but S.S. is held each week. Dr. Bishop was up for the week-end so he helped things along & Mrs. Helmick also - We sang & sang - then went to
our classes. As there were revival meetings up to the "Forks" (about 3 miles over I think) only 35 or so were present - There was a class of boys - little girls & then the rest of us were taken care of by Dr. B. - He is a M.E. minister - but very broadminded - the lesson was on missions - After this session - flew home & got out of my gray dress into dirty one & continued work - cleaning my room & doing a little washing - & by noon was cleaned up once more & on my way to the hotel with the rest of the crowd to have dinner with Mrs. Helmick - The hotel people sit at two long tables on the enclosed porch - & our party occupied all of one end - After dinner which con-
sisted of fried chicken - potatoes corn - beans - tomatoes - jelly - hot rolls - baked apples - lemon pie & watermelon we sat on the porch - I went over my work with Dr. B. which was a great help - then the rest of them went back to the house & I stayed & visited with Mrs. Helmick & Mrs. Huff. Finally Mrs. Helmick & I strolled over to the little old school on the hill opposite us where there is such a wonderful view of the mts. & talked Pi Phi. She told me a lot about the early beginnings of the school - all of which she knows as she was here & superintended much of the building - even helped out with the teaching & for five or six yrs. was the chief one in the committee - Now she is not connected with it in any way - but takes
a very keen interest in it & everyone around. We stayed there until the church bell rang about 9:30 for young peoples meeting - B.Y.P. it's called - so went down for that. More singing with a business meeting - electing officers etc. Evelyn had charge - & was like pulling teeth to get anyone started. Finally the new manual training teacher Mr. Cresswell (who had arrived from Sevierville during the p.m.) was put in for president. It was way after nine when we finally started home - Mrs. H. & the new man went up to the house - we had lunch & talked about the school & then bed time! Mr. C. is a very nice young fellow - grew up around here somewhere - has a farm - was in the army
& seems willing to do & start anything - He & two boys are now living in the house at the end of the road - a picture of which you have - They are at present having their meals here as the stove for that house has not yet arrived. He (Mr. C.) visited at school Monday & got the shop ready - Tuesday he took over my four mathematics classes & spelling - so now have four English classes - writing - U.S. History - geography - Latin & ancient history - We begin at 8 a.m. & have a 15 min. assembly of whole school - which we teachers take charge of a week at a time - 15 min. recess at 10 a.m. - 15 recess at 2 p.m. dismissing at 3 - with an hr. at noon
of course- Mondays & Wednesdays - my boys & girls (24 in no. at present) are all gone to sewing & m. training from 2 to 3 - but I have all of Abbie's youngsters to keep in order - Today they studied hard for about 25 min. & then I showed them some games until dismissal - Both Monday & yesterday p.m. I put in writing & took a few pictures also - Last evening as I was going down to feed the pig - yes I had a big bucket of slops - Emma Maples one of my girls arrived with her brother & two youngsters in their Ford - having brought us some gasoline - Emma walked down with me to the pig's dwelling which is down the walk past the cornfield &
school house - way over at the end of our land - On our way back she said they were going up to the Forks (along Fightin' Creek) to the other Maples family where her mother was visiting & bring her back - She wondered if I'd like to go - Of course I said yes & getting Emily piled in & off - We just flew up & down & over bumps - along a winding hilly road by Fightin' Creek - It gets dark so early now - & by the time we reached the house it was real dark - but lovely & starlight no wrap necessary either - The two boys in this family - Rellie & Ephraim are in my room - & very nice - Their house is a large frame farmhouse - with a big porch all around - and here
were Mr. & Mrs. Maples in bed - We sat down & visited cheerfully as though they had been up & dressed in chairs - Finally Mrs. Maples got up - the other (Emma's mother) was also in bed & arose - The boys were up & Emma's married sister - We wound up with a big watermelon - (am getting very fond of it - you don't know what a real melon is back there) & a pressing invitation to stay all night - In the front room was a bed - several big chairs & a table - While there must have been about a dozen enlarged family portraits on the walls - They are very nice people & we are going up again & stay. Today the excitement was a picnic of girls in Abbie's room & mine - Twenty seven of us in -
cluding Evelyn - Abbie - & myself climbed up the hill beyond the school and above the place in the road where I took a snap of Miss Abbott & her car - Here on top of the hill was a great broad shady expanse of level ground - wild purple asters in blossom near by & pennyroyal all over the steep sides of the hill! We played "ship-comes-in" while cooling off - a game they didn't know - also 3 deep another one new to them and then started our lunch - For our share we took "light bread" as white raised bread is called & butter - also juice of blackberries & lemons which made a fine cooling drink when we added water - They brought tomatoes (this is certainly tomato land- they eat them like apples) crackers - jelly - sausage
two pies - apples - cookies. This sounds like more than it was - for we came home & ate as much supper as usual about 7 - an hour later! Then we ran races - girls ran according to their sizes - with some left over apple quarters for prizes - I ran & lost my heel - also got quite dirty before getting home as we climbed several fences en route. Wore that one piece heavy white dress I got at McCormack's - It's so comfortable - am quite crazy about it I would like to wear it all the time. We are going to organize these girls into club tomorrow night something on the order of Girl Reserve'ss perhaps - Anyway - they meet in my room & elect officers
choose names etc. Next week am going to have them work up a party for the boys - After supper - Emily - Cora Ogle one of my girls & I took a jaunt up the road along Little Pigeon - & since then have been scribbling away to you fast as my pencil will go - must now cease my prating & hie me to bed - Am glad the little Dodge is not going over these awful roads - Hope all is well & that I hear again soon - Oh yes - we have put off our Smoky Mt. trip another week for various reasons - Well once more dear one farewell & adieu with very much love - Ruth
